title: CTRL0000916071 - Transcribed Interview of Elaine Chao, (August 4, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 2:03 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a transcribed interview of
Secretary Elaine Chao conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the
January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
Secretary Chao, thank you very much for being here.
your full name and spell your last name for the record?
The full name is Elaine L. Chao, C-h-a-o.
Counsel, if you could introduce yourselves as well.
And you are represented, I see, by counsel.
And my name is James Burnham, J-a-m-e-s, B-u-r-n-h-a-m, from
investigative counsel to the select committee.
and the last name is Crosland, C-r-o-s-1-a-n-d.
With me from the committee today are
This will be a staff-led interview.
If any members of the committee join via the
Webex platform, I will stop and note their presence, Secretary Chao, so you will be aware
Sometimes they may choose to ask a question and we'll facilitate that as well.
There's an official reporter who is transcribing the record of the interview.
Please wait until each question's complete before you begin your response, and we will
try to wait until your response before asking our next question.
the court reporter can't record nonverbal answers, like shaking your head.
important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
We just ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If a question isn't clear, then just ask for clarification.
And if you don't know the answer,
Although this interview is not under oath, it's voluntary, I just have to remind
you -- and this is not specific to you, this is a standard admonition -- that it is unlawful to
deliberately provide false information to Congress.
Do you understand all of those guide rules before we get started?
And, obviously, if you need a break at anytime, if you want
to consult with counsel, or if you just need a break for any purpose, just say the word and
Secretary Chao, let's -- again, thank you.
want to make clear from the outset that you're here voluntarily, not pursuant to a
subpoena or any process, and just on behalf of the committee, wanted to thank you again
I do want to show you one document, which I believe your counsel have already
received, it's exhibit 1, and it's a letter from the current White House Counsel's Office.
_ , if you can put that on the screen.
This is a letter, Secretary Chao, that was sent, I believe, to your counsel and copied
to us, that indicates that the current White House Counsel does not believe that any
assertion of executive privilege would be appropriate based on questions that we intend
Do you have any questions about this or understand the views of the current
So let's just start with a little bit about your background.
_ , you can take that back down.
extensive and impressive record in public service, and I would love for you to start from
your time at Mount Holyoke and Harvard Business School and just give us a quick
summary of all of the interesting and impressive things you've done since then.
I went to college and then to business school.
America, and was subsequently asked to come back as a deputy maritime administrator.
subsequent to that, director of the Peace Corps.
and was nominated and confirmed for the Secretary of Transportation in 2017.
Then was a White House fellow.
I went back to banking, to Bank of
And then I was chairman of the Federal Maritime
And subsequent to that, deputy secretary of Transportation.
And then president and CEO of United
And I left that to go with a think tank, and then was nominated for
And then left in 2009 and went into the private sector again,
And served until your resignation on January 7th of 2021?
What have you been doing since leaving the job as Secretary of Transportation?
And we'll come back to that.
I've been spending some time with my family, much neglected I have to say.
And I'm also now professionally with a think tank, I'm on a number of boards, nonprofit
and corporate boards, and I'm enjoying life.
I'm looking forward to being able to say that at some point in the
Spending time with family in particular.
So let's go right to January 6th.
Were you in Washington or elsewhere?
But I didn't pay attention -- very much attention to it.
So I take it you had no involvement in discussions of speakers or
planning for the Ellipse or other events planned for that day in Washington?
Were you aware of plans, Secretary Chao, before the 6th, for the
Ellipse rally at which President Trump spoke?
I would love to just begin with where you were
Had you heard anything prior to the 6th about the possibility of civil
unrest or violence anywhere associated with that event or at the Capitol?
Privy to any intelligence about crowds gathering or expectations for those
I take it, then, that you didn't attend the rally at the Ellipse, the
How did you first, then, become aware of violence at the Capitol?
I was at the Department, and I was taking farewell photographs with
So there was a long line, and that took about the afternoon.
assistant came in at about, I think, 3:30, and said that the Capitol had been breached, I
So before that moment when your assistant gave you that notice,
you were not aware of anything from television or other sources?
I was taking photographs with departing --
Did you watch or listen to the President's speech or
have any information about what he said at the Ellipse?
When you got that word at, you said around 3:30, what if any official
action did you take in your position as the Secretary in the wake of or upon notice of the
I was in the middle of taking pictures.
There was a long queue of
colleagues who were waiting a long time to take their photograph.
quite understand what the assistant told me, squeezed in between all of these, you know,
At some point, did you get additional information and more clarity about
what was going on at the Capitol?
It was probably at the end of the day.
After the violence had been essentially stopped or law enforcement
I'm just trying to get a sense of when you were sort of fully aware of
I don't know, because I wasn't aware of what was -- too
much as to what was happening.
There were so many things happening at the
So I can't tell you when the violence stopped because I wasn't sure at that
And the Department of Transportation is some distance from the
It didn't require any physical security or anything like that within the
At any point on January 6th, did you talk to
or attempt to talk to anyone at the White House?
Did you reach out to the President, the chief of staff, anyone there, once you
Did you -- have you ever learned of others who had conversations with
How about the Vice President or any members of his staff?
If you didn't have them, anyone recount for
you that they had conversations with him that day?
You mean at that time or afterwards?
I'm just wondering if you're aware of who the
President may have spoken to during the day of January 6th.
Aside from what I've read in the newspapers, I don't have any idea.
And I appreciate that answer, Secretary Chao.
your personal knowledge, not the stuff that you have read about in the newspaper, and I
No, I don't -- I don't know of anybody personally that had spoken with him.
How about other members of the Cabinet?
aware that afternoon or evening of violence, did you have conversations with any of your
There -- there was one person who publicly, I think, said that they
spoke with me, but I have very little recollection.
Secretary Scalia actually has been before the select committee, and
he has, yes, exactly, said that he believes he had a conversation with you, that you called
him that evening, the evening of January 6th.
Do you remember speaking to Secretary Scalia that evening?
Do you remember speaking to him at any time about the events at the
Capitol, or tell us then about, even if you can't place it in time, the first conversation you
So we would speak labor issues when he was Secretary.
I did not talk to him about resignation.
He and I speak about labor issues because I was a Labor
Did you ever talk to him about January 6th and about your decision
Scalia indicated in his testimony that you discussed the attack on the
Capitol and how horrible it was; that you asked him what you thought they, meaning the
some more, and that you and he agreed to talk again on the 7th.
He replied that he was disturbed but wanted to think about it
Again, does his description of that conversation refresh your recollection or help
you recall a conversation like that with James Scalia?
A little bit, vaguely, but I don't remember too much about the details.
Beyond what I just read, Secretary Scalia's recollection, do you have
anything else that was discussed with him?
It was a pretty shocking day.
Obviously, for everyone, but I get -- I got the sense from
Secretary Scalia that you were -- his view was that you were reaching out for him, looking
for some advice or some guidance about what the appropriate response was.
Did you reach out to others for advice and guidance as you contemplated
what to do in the wake of the violence at the Capitol?
The decision you made was strictly yours and not informed by discussions
Do you remember whether you spoke to any other colleagues in the Cabinet
I don't speak that often with other colleagues.
Do you recall talking with Secretary Scalia about the 25th
Amendment, the possible Cabinet invocation of the 25th Amendment?
How about others, did you ever participate in a conversation on that topic
Secretary Scalia has testified also that he suggested, and I believe this was
the next day, that the Cabinet should convene, should actually have a meeting with the
President to discuss decisionmaking for the last couple of weeks of the administration.
Do you remember discussing that prospect of a Cabinet meeting with Secretary
You know, this is the waning days of the administration.
was focused on, helping them get placed, helping to out-place them, helping them get
jobs, and, you know, basically tidying up, getting organized and leaving.
I was very concerned about my appointees, and that's what I
Of course, completely understand, Secretary Chao.
a very shocking day and one that led to your resignation, which I'll get to.
decision to leave even a couple of weeks early.
I'm just wondering if you consulted with
-- given Secretary Scalia's testimony that you had a conversation with him.
I would not even -- Secretary Scalia is an honorable man.
have said it if it didn't happen, but I have no recollection of it.
consulted him or anybody else on that kind of a decision.
You know -- when did I make the decision?
Tell us when you made the decision to resign.
That's kind of a hard question
It kind of developed as more information came in as to what happened and
the full ramifications of the actions that were taken by some people and the results that
I think it was -- it was developing.
But as I mentioned, when I was first told, I didn't understand what that -- I mean,
it was so inconceivable, I didn't understand it.
Then I had a full day of events that I had to go
through, and it was probably at the end of the day that, you know, I -- I probably learned,
turned on the television, for example.
of the day that I began to kind of pay more attention, obviously, and the full weight of
what had happened, and then seeing the visuals weighed on me.
I don't know, but it was probably toward the end
You said that the full ramifications of actions taken by some people.
Tell us more about what you mean by that.
who were those people, and how did that influence your decision?
How did that -- what were those actions,
I mean, the bravery of the U.S. Capitol Police
and, you know, those who were hurt, those who were trying to defend the Capitol, and
then the actions of the intruders and how they broke through the glass.
I did not actually see too much footage on the rally outside.
the break-in, the attack on the Capitol itself.
I'm curious as to how the bravery of the police or the violence of the
rioters made you think that resignation was appropriate.
Tell us more about why that
became, in your mind, and you took that action that you needed to step away from your
Your resignation letter, first to President Trump, discussed the accomplishments
Well, I think my statement, which came out the following morning, speaks
I'll just read a couple of parts of that and ask you to comment on it.
of the Department during his administration.
Lastly, I had planned on serving through to the end of your term in office, but after
yesterday's events at the U.S. Capitol, I will resign as U.S. Secretary of Transportation
effective Monday, January 11th, to provide a short period of transition.
And you said, Lastly -- this is a quote:
So tell me more, why it is, again, that instead of serving until the end of the
administration, the events at the Capitol made you leave early?
I think the events at the Capitol, however they occurred, were shocking, and
it was something that, as I mentioned in my statement, that I could not put aside.
Did you have trouble continuing to serve in President Trump's Cabinet
because of his actions that led to or moved people toward the Capitol that day?
You know, it's always -- it used to be that it is an honor to serve.
President asked you to serve, there's only one answer.
impossible for me to continue, given my personal values and my philosophy.
I came as an immigrant to this country.
decision that I made on my own.
I am grateful for the opportunity
And at a particular point, the events were such that it was
And so I was -- it was a
I understand, Secretary Chao, and I, again, very much appreciate that
I guess my question is, did you feel like President Trump somehow failed to meet
the moment on January 6th, and that resulted in you being unable to continue to serve,
even for 10 more days, in his Cabinet?
I wish that he had acted differently, yes.
Well, you have heard of many, many people offer suggestions.
wish that he had called a halt to the violence.
Did you, at any point over the course of the day, encourage him to do so,
I did not call him, nor -- I did not -- yeah, I did not call him.
Are you aware of others who did and yet he refused to call a
halt, in your words, to the violence?
I'm not -- I was not in conversation with other people who had called him.
Why was it, Secretary Chao, that his failure to act sooner was of
such magnitude that you felt like you needed to leave immediately as opposed to stay
through the end of the term?
Explain that decision more if you can.
Well, I think in politics, once you say you're leaving, you're leaving, and
transition for my successor, to take care of loose ends with those who have worked with
So I stayed around for 4 days to facilitate a good
to finish that to make sure that they were taken care of.
But Secretary Scalia, for instance, decided to stay until the
very end, and you did not.
hasten your plans to leave as opposed to continue to do -- to facilitate the transition
And I'm curious, again, as to why you felt like you needed to
Well, Secretary Scalia had his reasons, as did others, for staying.
that day were such that I just could not stay.
And as I stated in my resignation statement, I think the events of
In your letter to your colleagues at the Department of Transportation, which
you, I think, actually posted on Twitter, you were a bit more explicit in your
condemnation of the President's role in the attack and said this about your decision:
Yesterday our country experienced a traumatic and entirely avoidable event as
supporters of the President stormed the Capitol building following a rally he addressed.
As I am sure is the case with many of you, it has deeply troubled me in a way that I simply
So let me just ask you about a couple of the words that you chose.
What did you mean when you said that the events of the 6th at the
could've put a stop to the rampage and to the violence.
Well, as I said in the beginning as you started to ask me, my statement
But I think avoidable means, you know, hopefully he and others
So your view was, if he had more forcefully called a halt to it or
condemned the violence, it would not have escalated to the point that it did?
I think that's an accurate assessment.
You also, in your letter to your colleagues at the Department, say
that supporters of the President stormed the Capitol building following a rally he
addressed, essentially connecting the storming to the address.
Tell me more about your view of how his words impacted the actions of the
Well, at that time, I didn't know fully what his words were, but they were
enough to -- and, also, it was reported as such that he had, instead of asking his
supporters to go home -- and he did do that later on but not at the outset.
And, you know, if the rally hadn't happened, maybe the breach of the Capitol
Maybe if some people had spoken more evenly and talked
more about, you know, our democratic institutions, without stirring people's passions and
inflaming some of the very earnest but excited supporters, perhaps all of this would not
So it sounds like you believed that
his words at the Ellipse bore some responsibility for the violence that occurred at the
Well, they did not calm things down, and that was a possibility and an option
You say in your letter that it has deeply troubled you in a way that you
to it and why it was such that you just could no longer serve in the very important role in
Tell us more about the sort of emotional reaction that you had
Well, I think it -- when something as basic as a discussion of what our
democracy is supposed to be like, when that doesn't jibe with your own personal
philosophy, I think it's time to go.
I called the chief of staff.
Tell us about the conversation with him.
It was the morning of January 7th, and I said to him basically what I said in
When you made your decision to resign, did you notify anyone
Did you call the President or anyone at the White House?
my resignation statement, and said that I had planned to announce my departure shortly.
Did he provide any pushback or any feedback to you about
He basic- -- I can't remember what he said, but it was a short
He was -- I mean, he took the message and said that he would relay it to
I think we both knew at that time that that was not going to be a successful
Did he try to talk you out of it?
Did he express any of his personal views about what had occurred at
Did he characterize it in any way similar to how you felt about those events?
He did not say -- he did not express his own opinions.
Did he give you any information about his role in encouraging the
President to do something the previous day or give you any information about what he
You weren't the only Cabinet member who resigned that day.
Did you ever speak with her about her decision to resign at the same time?
I think I resigned ahead of her.
And it was around the same time.
to her about her decision or yours?
How about, again, other members of the Cabinet, after you
resigned, did you explain to them your decision, discuss why you took the steps you did?
Now, going back to Secretary Scalia, he indicated that part of the reason that
he did not resign is that he was concerned that the President might put someone worse
in, in the wake of that.
similarly said his decision about resignation was informed by fear that there could be sort
of a worse -- was their term -- installed leader.
install someone worse than you or you -- was that at all a factor in your decision?
Did you have any of those concerns, Secretary Chao, that the President could
And we've heard that from others.
I ran a pretty organized Department, and we knew who would
be the next person when I stepped down.
I assume that would be -- the deputy secretary would ascend to become
And did that occur, the acting deputy became the
Did you seek to convey your decision directly to the
I mean, he's the person that had hired you.
directly to inform him about your reasons for resignation?
Did you want to talk to him
I don't think that would've been a useful -- I don't think that would've been a
He probab- -- he has his own point of view.
I have my point of view.
I did the courtesy of notifying him, through his chief of staff, in advance of my
worried that it would be a bad, acrimonious conversation?
When you say you didn't think it would be productive, I think was the word
you used, or constructive, tell me more about that.
I'm not so sure what would've been the point.
know, they want -- they wanted something.
Most people like to talk because they want to make -- you
Why did you fear it wouldn't be a
I mean, it was pretty clear what had
It was a personal and private decision.
notified the White House of my decision prior to the announcement.
I didn't owe anything to anyone.
And as a matter of courtesy, I
So, again, I won't belabor this, but you don't recall
consulting with anyone else about this before you made the decision, it was strictly
Before we leave January 6th, let me just make sure if there's -- I
understand you didn't try to call anyone at the White House.
in the Capitol over the course of the afternoon?
Did you talk to any people
And I'm not trying to pry into --
I'm just curious if you reached out, in concern
or otherwise, to people who were literally victims who were there in secure locations in
I checked in on my husband.
I mean, I hope it's understood, you know, in the -- it was a transition.
I've been through transitions before, and there are lots of things to do.
and there's a lot of things to wrap up.
I cared about my Department, I cared about my people, and I was trying to, you
know, make sure that the Department was ready to receive the next Secretary.
was -- it was pretty busy, so --
I know you have a lot of close relationships with people across
government, and I'm just wondering if you reached out -- again, I appreciate that you
called your husband to check on him, but were there others, friends, professional
colleagues, about whom you were concerned and potentially reach out to express that
Actually, I'm not a very -- no, I did not.
Not that I didn't care about
them, but I'm not the kind of person that gets on the phone and just, like, gossips a lot.
recount to you the things that he said over the course of the afternoon via Twitter?
The President issued a series of tweets or statements over the course of the
Were you aware of them in real time, following them, or had anyone
I think you said before that you weren't even aware that there was any issue
at the Capitol until 3-something in the afternoon and presumably wasn't aware of
No, because, again, that afternoon -- if you have a group of people, they're
all waiting for you and they're -- they're in a line, and you're offering them -- this is the
first time they've had -- this is the last time they think they're going to see the Secretary.
And, you know, these are people we've worked together and it's an opportunity
for me and each person just to chat a little bit, you know, about how are you and what's
going on, because these opportunities don't come that often.
So I had a line of people, and I was greeting and chatting with these, you know,
colleagues, and they were looking forward to it.
looking forward to the photograph with the Secretary and the 2 minutes or whatever
they can get with the Secretary to speak with her, and I wanted to make those moments,
you know, memorable, and good ones for my colleagues.
They got all dressed up, and they were
The President at 2:24 tweeted -- the first thing he said during the riot was:
Pence didn't have the courage to do what should've been done to protect our country
It was openly critical of the Vice President.
I'm wondering if you ever, at any
point, talked to the Vice President about his decision, what he did on January 6th,
anything having to do with that day.
And I did not learn of that sentence until much further on.
And I appreciate that you didn't know about it in real time.
you did hear about that statement, what was your reaction, much later on?
It's a very unkind, unfair statement on a Vice President who was extremely
How do you feel, Secretary Chao, about what Vice President Pence
himself did during the joint session, his decision to certify the duly submitted electors
from the States around the country?
The Vice President did what was right.
He did -- he carried out his
Have you ever, to this day, conveyed that to him, that respect and
appreciation for what he did that day?
I don't think -- there was maybe -- at a funeral.
And was that just pleasantry or discussion of --
-- that you respect and appreciate what --
So no subsequent contact with Vice President Pence?
We were there at -- I think it was -- I can't remember whose funeral
it was, we were there at the same time.
Pretty much after an administration people scatter.
So it sounds like you've never talked to Vice President Pence about
The President did, as you said earlier, Secretary Chao,
eventually on the 6th, it was at 4:17, issue a video statement from the Rose Garden in
have to have peace, so go home.
I know your pain, I know your hurt.
We had an election that was stolen
It was a landslide election, and everyone knows it.
But you have to go home
We can't play into the hands of these people.
We love you, you're very special.
When you eventually learned of this, what was your reaction?
some of them got very violent, and such warm words were not really appropriate.
Well, I think the reaction from even Republicans was that it was
These supporters may have started out being very well-intentioned, but
We have heard that from a lot of witnesses, yes, a lot of
I'm just wondering you, sort of you personally, when you heard that, when
telling people to go home, he said that he loved them and that they were very special, to
give us more of your reaction to that.
Again, I didn't hear of these words until like later on in the evening.
Having seen on television what happened, it was clearly -- more was needed.
Those were not the right words.
Anything else, Secretary Chao, from the day of January 6th that
you recall that might be relevant, any conversation, any memory of yours about your
personal experience, your thoughts, feelings, conversations, from that day?
It was a busy time, and I don't recall very much about
January -- you know, about the specifics of what you're asking about January 6th at all.
I mean, it must've been a very difficult day to abruptly leave a job
that you presumably loved, did very well, were planning on continuing, just like that.
Tell us more, if you can, about sort of how it felt to quit like that, abruptly, in the wake of
colleagues, political appointees, who were going to be out of a job.
realizing, never understanding that political appointees don't serve forever.
Well, we were going to leave.
So we were in the process of getting ready
I would've liked a little bit more time, again, so that I could've helped my
Many of them were very young.
This is the first time they've ever faced a loss.
And it was scary, it was frightening.
terms of recommendations, in terms of helping them, you know, get new jobs.
And I wanted to be able to be a backstop to them in
And I've always done that, where -- you know, everybody who's ever worked with
me, I take care of them.
Did any of the people that worked with you at Transportation resign
similar to you, make the same decision that they were going to abruptly leave because of
Tell me more about conversations with them.
Who were they and why did
appointees, except for the Administrator at the Federal Aviation Administration who,
similarly, after I resigned, made a similar deci- -- made the same decision of leaving early,
I think a day afterwards or something like that.
And I understand that you didn't encourage them to leave, but did
you have discussions with them about their decisions about why they similarly felt that
they wanted to resign because of January 6th?
Did they notify you, much like you had notified Mr. Meadows?
word from some or all of them that they were also resigning?
I smile because, by that time, I don't think -- I don't think I was the Secretary
So if they told anybody, it would've been to the Acting Secretary.
So you were there through the 11th, I guess, officially.
recall any discussions with any of your deputies or the administrators of the component
agencies about this topic, about whether to stay or go?
That was also over a weekend.
So I think the 7th was a Thursday.
I'm sorry, the 6th was a Wednesday, you're right.
And so there was only -- and then Thursday, you know, the
announcement was made, like, late morning.
even -- actually, that's something to remember.
And because of COVID, we weren't
We weren't even all together because
And there was only Friday that was a workday, and
Let me just -- a couple of things about the 25th
Do you remember talking to anyone about the possible invocation of the 25th
Anyone at all that had -- I guess I'm not talking about a neighbor, but anyone
who potentially had a professional, relevant role to play in the consideration of whether
that amendment was or wasn't, you know, potentially appropriately invoked, other
members of the Cabinet, the Vice President, others who would consider it in Congress.
Did you talk to anyone like that about the 25th Amendment?
There have been a lot of reports about Cabinet discussions.
Pompeo, Secretary Mnuchin, you know, discussed this openly.
were a party to any of those conversations about whether or not the Cabinet should
invoke the 25th Amendment and seek potentially to have the Vice President step in for
They did not approach me, and I was not aware of any discussions within the
Did you have any personal concerns about sort of the mental fitness of the
Separate from conversations, did you have concerns that
maybe the 25th Amendment would be appropriate?
By that time, I did not have personal contact with him.
1did not go to the White House, there were no meetings, so I hadn't been in
But based on his action or inaction, did you have
concerns that perhaps there was a mental health issue or instability sufficient that we
Well, he has his point of view, and he has very strong opinions, like most
But I did not discuss that with anyone in the Cabinet, nor did
whether you had any concerns about his decision making based on what happened on
January 6th, practical concerns that steps needed to be taken to land the plane, to
stabilize government in the last 2 weeks?
I was not close enough to him.
people getting to him, I was not aware of that at that time.
Secretary Chao, in all of the weeks and months since January 6th,
have you had other conversations with people about their personal experience that day?
And, again, when I say people, I mean people that were directly affected,
government officials, Members of Congress, and, again, I'm setting aside your husband
Obviously what happened that day was very
disturbing, and I've made my position and my feelings quite clear by taking the strongest
Then after that, you know, there are other things to do.
had to personally get transitioned into my private life, get resettled again.
bigger -- it's a big issue, but I don't talk about it with, you know, with -- with other
Cabinet -- I haven't had very many discussions with Cabinet officers since leaving.
I guess I'm just wondering if you learned anything more from people
about their personal experience, particularly people in the White House, about what was
happening that day, what the mood was, what was -- what were people encouraging the
President to do, anything factual like that that you learned from other people anytime
I mean, I just read the public reports, newspapers, like
I'm not looking for public reports.
wondering if you recall any conversation with people about their lived experience that
I really haven't talked to very many of them at all.
Let me pause here and s e e , _ if you have
I don't think we have any Members on the line.
Not Cabinet members, not White House officials?
